data.meta_description: Classic Romance - Christchurch City Libraries by  ChristchurchLib - a staff-created list : Most romance novels published after World War II are considered ‘modern’. Anything prior to that is considered classic, with the heyday being the turn of the century. Typically featuring prudish women that harbour secret desires, pompous men of importance who turn out to have a heart of gold, and family, legal, or societal pressures getting in the way of love and becoming a head-ache for all involved. Even if you’ve never read Pride and Prejudice, you’ve heard of it, proving the consistent popularity of the romance genre - these titles are where it all began.

To be honest, this list could include every single one of Jane Austen’s works but for the sake of brevity we’ll focus on the most well-known. Since its im...Show more To be honest, this list could include every single one of Jane Austen’s works but for the sake of brevity we’ll focus on the most well-known. Since its immediate success in 1813, 'Pride and Prejudice' has remained one of the most popular novels in the English language. Darcy’s pride, Lizzie’s prejudice, misunderstandings, adorable side romances and Austen's acute observations and acerbic wit - what’s not to love? Show less

Set in the bleak Yorkshire Moors, this is a novel of transgression, passion and lust. This classically dark romance has achieved cult status through its h...Show more Set in the bleak Yorkshire Moors, this is a novel of transgression, passion and lust. This classically dark romance has achieved cult status through its haunting language and deft portrayal of an obsessive and dangerous love between Heathcliff and Cathy, identifying inherited trauma, isolation and 18th century struggles. The only novel written by Emily Brontë, who died a year after this book was published at age 30. Show less

Emma Bovary is the ultimate anti-heroine, seeking an all-encompassing, unattainable, almost otherworldly, passion. Her marriage to Dr Charles Bovary is qu...Show more Emma Bovary is the ultimate anti-heroine, seeking an all-encompassing, unattainable, almost otherworldly, passion. Her marriage to Dr Charles Bovary is quickly a disappointment in the romance department and so she embarks on a number of highly-charged affairs, with glimpses of all she ever wanted. Her material wants are as consuming as her romantic needs and she quickly racks up debts, her affairs fizzle out and Madame Bovary is then left to face her demons. A whirlwind novel full of excesses, devouring passions and true love - once decried as an obscene and immoral text but modern readers may sympathise more with Mme Bovary, a flesh and blood woman who wanted it all. Show less

If you like lots and lots of words with your romance, have I got a treat for you! Lauded as ‘the world’s greatest novel’ by some, and a 'a bit wordy' by o...Show more If you like lots and lots of words with your romance, have I got a treat for you! Lauded as ‘the world’s greatest novel’ by some, and a 'a bit wordy' by others, Anna Karenina is the tragic tale of a woman who leaves her emotionless marriage to find solace in the arms of the passionate Count Vronsky, and how society punishes them for their union. Split into eight parts, this definitely isn’t a light and fluffy summer romance read but it is a classical heavy-weight, full of a wealth of memorable characters, burning passion, tragedy and an enduring snap shot of the rapidly transforming landscape of Russia. Show less

A beautiful novel that flits between Italy and England as a brooding romance quietly develops between Miss Lucy Honeychurch and Mr George Emerson - anothe...Show more A beautiful novel that flits between Italy and England as a brooding romance quietly develops between Miss Lucy Honeychurch and Mr George Emerson - another pair whose romance is blighted by the restrictive societal norms of the day. Split into two main parts, this novel paints a picture of a developing realisation of love as our couple do not immediately hit it off and then there are other, more advantageous, engagements on the cards too. But when they meet again in England, what transpired in Italy brings these two lovers together. An optimistic novel and a humorous snapshot of the constraints of Edwardian England with a refreshingly forward-thinking young woman at the helm. Show less

In 'The Age of Innocence', Wharton looks at the pressures and hypocrisy of society in 20th century America. Newly separated from her husband, a dazzling c...Show more In 'The Age of Innocence', Wharton looks at the pressures and hypocrisy of society in 20th century America. Newly separated from her husband, a dazzling countess returns to New York to her cousins wedding, only to find the sensitive groom falling hopelessly in love with her. This touching classic makes for a poignant and perceptive read. Show less

Orphaned at a young age, Jane has experienced more than her fair share of hardship and loneliness. When she is employed by the rich and powerful Edward Ro...Show more Orphaned at a young age, Jane has experienced more than her fair share of hardship and loneliness. When she is employed by the rich and powerful Edward Rochester, she finds herself drawn to his enigmatic, brooding, complex nature, and Rochester is likewise taken by Jane's innocence, inner beauty and strength of character. What follows is an unconventional Victorian romance, a slow-burner, with painful twists and sorrows and a supernatural edge... as there's something stirring in the attic. An intimate and psychologically loaded novel, which reads as an in-depth social commentary and morality tale - a reader is truly immersed in Jane's world. For many, this is the ultimate romantic novel! Show less

If you like your romances dark, full of mystery with a touch of crime then this Gothic classic is for you! A naïve young woman is whisked away to a myster...Show more If you like your romances dark, full of mystery with a touch of crime then this Gothic classic is for you! A naïve young woman is whisked away to a mysterious country estate by an even more mysterious male suitor, she hastily marries him but soon discovers that things aren't all as they seem. A psychological horror with intruiging gender dynamics and a slither of romance. Certain editions of this book also join the ranks of gothic novels which feature a woman in a nightgown lost out in the dark, looking over her shoulder at an ominous mansion with a single lit window (seriously, Google it, it’s a real trope). Show less

All copies in use. Availability details

Published in 1869 but set in the late 17th century in the West Country, 'Lorna Doone' is the tale of two star-crossed lovers who are kept apart by a gener...Show more Published in 1869 but set in the late 17th century in the West Country, 'Lorna Doone' is the tale of two star-crossed lovers who are kept apart by a generations-old family feud. But great love cannot be denied, surely? Expect a lot of action, twists, and deaths in this absorbing tale because the course of true love certainly doesn't run smooth for John Ridd and Lorna Doone. Show less

Set in the American South in the era of the Civil War, 'Gone with the Wind' follows the headstrong Scarlett O'Hara, daughter of a well-off plantation owne...Show more Set in the American South in the era of the Civil War, 'Gone with the Wind' follows the headstrong Scarlett O'Hara, daughter of a well-off plantation owner. An absolute classic, this is a sweeping romantic story of love, war and adventure. If you like novels with determined, complex, but tremendously flawed protagonists, you'll be gripped by Scarlett's story. The war causes the world as she knew it to crumble around her, but Scarlett is a survivor (and a canny one at that). Disclaimer: includes themes of slavery and racism. Show less

Considered to be one of the great American novels - it's quick, flashy and not all for show! This is a beautifully written story of love, obsession, greed...Show more Considered to be one of the great American novels - it's quick, flashy and not all for show! This is a beautifully written story of love, obsession, greed and frivolity, set in the Jazz Age. Semi-autobiographical, this novel has cemented F. Scott Fitzgerald’s legacy as a master craftsman. Dive into the glittering world of absurd parties, love triangles and unfulfilled American dreams. Show less

All copies in use. Availability details

If you're in the mood for a good old "rescue the princess" story then look no further - this classic adventure romance should be your next read!...Show more If you're in the mood for a good old "rescue the princess" story then look no further - this classic adventure romance should be your next read! If you enjoyed the film then definitely pick up the book, though be prepared for a slightly less optimistic view of things. Like the film, the book contains a wonderful array of characters, epic swordsmanship, real villains, danger, cheesy one-liners and plenty of satirical humour. Show less

A much darker read than some classic romance novels, this Gothic romance is a great read for fans who like their classics a bit grimmer. The captivating g...Show more A much darker read than some classic romance novels, this Gothic romance is a great read for fans who like their classics a bit grimmer. The captivating gypsy dancer Esmeralda finds herself in the middle of a love triangle (or pentagon, as it turns out), that could bring nothing but trouble. After catching the eyes of Phoebus (Captain of the Guard), Pierre Gringoire, and Archdeacon Frollo, whose obsessive lust for her is driving him mad and then there is Quasimodo, the hunchback who rings Notre Dame's bells. Quasimodo finds himself in the middle of this tragic love story when Esmeralda shows him kindness and inspires his love. Full of dark twists, bittersweet romances and an appreciation for Gothic architecture, this novel helped to cement Notre Dame de Paris as an enduring icon. Show less

Based around the lead character, Doctor Yuri Zhivago and set in Russia between the time of the First Russian Revolution of 1905 and World War II, it is a ...Show more Based around the lead character, Doctor Yuri Zhivago and set in Russia between the time of the First Russian Revolution of 1905 and World War II, it is a complex tale. Yes, once again, lots of words and lots of names, but worth burrowing through for an epic story that will tug at your heart-strings. Show less
